contents.title: Vue Event Modifiers Examples
contents.description: Catch when user press enter with Vue modifiers

children.value: directives to get an event and display something:

props.code:
<script setup>
    const message = ref('');
    
    const showMessage = function () {
        console.log(message);
    }
</script>

<template>
    <input v-model="message">
    <button type="submit" @click="showMessage">click me</button>
</template>

children.value: How to fire a method with press-key event?
Well, there is another modifier for this behavior, lets supposed that we need to tight a press-enter event and fire

props.code:
<script setup>
    const message = ref('');

    const showMessage = function () {
        console.log(message);
    }
</script>

<template>
    <input v-model="message" @keyup.enter="showMessage">
    <button type="submit" @click="showMessage">click me</button>
</template>

children.value: When user press enter and key up event is fired, it would catch the event and execute the method

,
well this would be ok in many scenarios like a search-box
For regular forms the event submit and it's modifiers like

props.code:
<script setup>
    const message = ref('');

    const showMessage = function () {
    console.log(message);
}
</script>

<template>
    <form @submit.prevent="showMessage">
        <input v-model="message">
        <button type="submit">click me</button>
    </form>
</template>

links.text: How to fire a method with press-key event?

Maybe in a real layout it would have a
How to print just the certificate?
Well we are going to an add a

props.code:
<button onclick="printCertificate()" class="fixed z-10 bg-blue-900 text-white bottom-0 right-0 m-10 py-2 px-4 rounded-full shadow-xl hover:text-yellow-600 focus:outline-none">
    Print
</button>

children.value: fixed z-10 bg-blue-900 text-white bottom-0 right-0 m-10 py-2 px-4 rounded-full shadow-xl hover:text-yellow-600 focus:outline-none
, so now we need to add a

props.code:
<script>
        function printCertificate() {
            const printContents = document.getElementById('certificate').innerHTML;
            const originalContents = document.body.innerHTML;
            document.body.innerHTML = printContents;
            window.print();
            document.body.innerHTML = originalContents;
        }
    </script>

contents.title: Optimize Blade Views
contents.description: Get faster views that would be great ranked for tools like google Lighthouse

children.value:
I want a great performance,
hopefully all lighthouse stats on green
Many browsers actually support the loading="lazy" attribute so use it on your images that are not loaded on the visual ratio when your site loads.
Minify your Javascript in my case I only have one file, but if you have more files laravel mix can attach them and minify them on production.
Protect your links with target blank using rel="noopener noreferrer" attribute, it prevents an attack called tabnapping.
Optimize the images by reducing the size and weight of images, you can use something like:
Take care about accesibility, there are some text color that simply does not contrast enough take that in mind, lighthouse offers some tips on that cases just follow them.
Use SSL certificate on your site, lighthouse take that in mind and your users a site without SSL cert looks like an unsafe site.
Use SVGs when you can, they are optimized for the web, or even better when you can use web.p format.
Take care about responsiveness of your site, it would not be a stat but definitely more people would visit your site first on mobile than desktop, so take that in mind.
Add SEO, with Laravel you can use SEOTOOLS package that is great and easy to use:
Add a sitemap.xml file to instruct the google crawler about your site pages, with again with Laravel it is easy using a SPATIE package:
If your site would add a newsletter you can use this useful package, from... you guess SPATIE:
Load Javascript only when is required, I only use alpineJS on contact form page so adding js scripts conditionally could help to load faster your site, here an example:
Add an alternative text to every image, even if its just an asset:

props.code: // on svgs you can use the title tag

children.value: // on svgs you can use the title tag
Optimize your Laravel application when you are going to make a deployment,
clear and cache again the config files, routes & views

props.code:
// clear cache
php artisan config:clear
php artisan route:clear
php artisan view:clear
// cache files
php artisan config:cache
php artisan route:cache
php artisan view:cache
php artisan optimize

children.value: Add cache on your server, if you are going to use NGINX you can set easily some configuration to cache assets like images or pdf files from one request to other by an amount of time that you can customize, here the configuration that I use on my site to compress config & cache assets:
You can handle all files in just one location block, but in my case as the PDF file in my site would not change as much, I separate it into another location block.

contents.title: Install PhpCsFixer in a Laravel Project
contents.description: Start using PHPCSFixer in your Laravel Projects and apply custom configurations

children.value: Code sniffer Fixer apply syntax rules to our
You can add your configuration rules
Here is a good example to use it in a laravel projects checking just a few rules
Another more advance example checking much more rules

props.code:
<?php

$finder = Symfony\Component\Finder\Finder::create()
    ->in([
        __DIR__ . '/tests',
    ])
    ->in(__DIR__)
    ->exclude(['bootstrap', 'storage', 'vendor','docker'])
    ->name('*.php')
    ->name('_ide_helper')
    ->notName('*.blade.php')
    ->ignoreDotFiles(true)
    ->ignoreVCS(true);

return (new PhpCsFixer\Config())
    ->setRules([
        '@PSR12' => true,
        'array_syntax' => ['syntax' => 'short'],
        'ordered_imports' => ['sort_algorithm' => 'alpha'],
        'no_unused_imports' => true,
        'not_operator_with_successor_space' => true,
        'trailing_comma_in_multiline' => true,
        'phpdoc_scalar' => true,
        'unary_operator_spaces' => true,
        'binary_operator_spaces' => true,
        'blank_line_before_statement' => [
            'statements' => ['break', 'continue', 'declare', 'return', 'throw', 'try'],
        ],
        'phpdoc_single_line_var_spacing' => true,
        'phpdoc_var_without_name' => true,
        'class_attributes_separation' => [
            'elements' => [
                'method' => 'one',
            ],
        ],
        'method_argument_space' => [
            'on_multiline' => 'ensure_fully_multiline',
            'keep_multiple_spaces_after_comma' => true,
        ],
        'single_trait_insert_per_statement' => true,
    ])
    ->setFinder($finder);

children.value: Feel free to use whatever configuration that makes sense for your project
You can add more flags to customize the behavior of the fixer, like
and execute any of these commands automatically, following this post

contents.title: Install PHPInsights
contents.description: Start using PHPInsights in your Laravel App

children.value: PHP Insights is a great tool for static code analysis, it adds a review about your code on four different areas,

project there are some custom rules
that would help to start to work with the project as soon as possible
Using PHPInsights with a Laravel Project

By default, it will show some tips (first ones) to fix the code base,
the package has four categories to review
To check all tips at once

file you can instruct the package
to avoid changing the framework & third party packages codebase

props.code:
'exclude' => [
        'app/Actions/Jetstream',
        'HandleInertiaRequests.php',
        '_ide_macros.php'
    ],

'add' => [
    Classes::class => [
        ForbiddenFinalClasses::class,
    ],
],

'remove' => [
    AlphabeticallySortedUsesSniff::class,
    DeclareStrictTypesSniff::class,
    DisallowMixedTypeHintSniff::class,
    ForbiddenDefineFunctions::class,
    ForbiddenNormalClasses::class,
    ForbiddenTraits::class,
    ParameterTypeHintSniff::class,
    PropertyTypeHintSniff::class,
    ReturnTypeHintSniff::class,
    UselessFunctionDocCommentSniff::class,
    UnusedParameterSniff::class,
    LineLengthSniff::class,
    DocCommentSpacingSniff::class,
    ClassInstantiationSniff::class,
    NewWithBracesFixer::class,
    NullableTypeForNullDefaultValueSniff::class,
    DisallowArrayTypeHintSyntaxSniff::class,
    NoEmptyCommentFixer::class,
    DisallowShortTernaryOperatorSniff::class,
    ForbiddenPublicPropertySniff::class,
    DisallowEmptySniff::class
],

contents.title: Basic Github Actions for Laravel
contents.description: Start using Github Actions in your Laravel Projects with two basic workflows

children.value: file that is just a copy from

,
feel free to adjust this files for your project requirements
Select the action that fits better for your project
Github Action to run PHPUnit test

props.code:
name: CI
on:
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  tests:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 
    services:
      mysql:
        image: mysql:8.0
        env:
          MYSQL_ALLOW_EMPTY_PASSWORD: yes
          MYSQL_DATABASE: test
        ports:
          - 3306:3306
        options: --health-cmd="mysqladmin ping" --health-interval=10s --health-timeout=5s --health-retries=3
 
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      with:
        fetch-depth: 1
        
    - name: Cache composer dependencies
      uses: actions/cache@v2
      with:
        path: vendor
        key: composer-${{ hashFiles('**/composer.lock') }}
        restore-keys: |
          composer-
          
    - name: Install PHP
      uses: shivammathur/setup-php@v2
      with:
        php-version: 8.1
 
    - name: Install composer dependencies
      run: |
        composer install --no-scripts
 
    - name: Prepare Laravel Application
      run: |
        cp .env.ci .env
        php artisan key:generate
 
    - name: Run Test suite
      run: php artisan test

children.value: Github Action to run PHPUnit tests & NPM workflow

props.code:
name: CI
on:
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - main
  push:
    branches:
      - main

jobs:
  tests:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
 
    services:
      mysql:
        image: mysql:8.0
        env:
          MYSQL_ALLOW_EMPTY_PASSWORD: yes
          MYSQL_DATABASE: test
        ports:
          - 3306:3306
        options: --health-cmd="mysqladmin ping" --health-interval=10s --health-timeout=5s --health-retries=3
 
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      with:
        fetch-depth: 1
        
    - name: Cache composer dependencies
      uses: actions/cache@v2
      with:
        path: vendor
        key: composer-${{ hashFiles('**/composer.lock') }}
        restore-keys: |
          composer-
          
    - name: Install PHP
      uses: shivammathur/setup-php@v2
      with:
        php-version: 8.1
 
    - name: Install composer dependencies
      run: |
        composer install --no-scripts
 
    - name: Prepare Laravel Application
      run: |
        cp .env.ci .env
        php artisan key:generate
 
    - name: Run Test suite
      run: php artisan test

    - name: Install NPM dependencies
      run: npm install
      
    - name: Compile assets
      run: npm run build

contents.title: Lint and Fix your Laravel Code with Duster and Husky
contents.description: Lint and Fix your Laravel Code with Duster and Husky

children.value:
Duster is an opinionated linter and fixer for Laravel code, that takes the best of Laravels Pint,
together with the power of PHP_CodeSniffer and PHP-CS-Fixer
Duster works on the command line, with
During installation & setup process I found a little issue related to
so here I share the solutions
Check that your project has git initialized
If not you can initialize it with

props.code:
#!/usr/bin/env sh
. "$(dirname -- "$0")/_/husky.sh"
npx --no-install lint-staged

npm run test # this line should be removed

children.value: your codebase, you can use the Duster
command in order to fix the code base automatically.
It will publish a github action workflow for Duster, you can configure it and read more about Duster in

children.value: There are cases when is required to fire an
, there are two ways of handle this actions
Let's suppose we want to send a

attempt() -> login() -> fireLoginEvent() -> new Login event
In this example you need to create your listener

Where Is Fired The Registered Event?

Where Is Fired The Verified Event?
* Mark the authenticated user's email address as verified.

The same way you can handle this approach as an
Where Is Fired The Logout Event?
* Log the user out of the application.
// If we have an event dispatcher instance, we can fire off the logout event
// so any further processing can be done. This allows the developer to be
// listening for anytime a user signs out of this application manually.
So you can use the event to fire a
